April 7, 2002: Fiction
EVERYTHING'S EVENTUAL, by Stephen King. (Scribner, $28.) A collection of 14
"dark tales" about the strange and the supernatural.
2ND CHANCE, by James Patterson with Andrew Gross. (Little, Brown, $26.95.)
The members of the Women's Murder Club -- a detective, a medical examiner, a
prosecutor and a reporter -- search for a killer.
THE SUMMONS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) A law professor who
has been called home to Mississippi by his father, a dying judge, discovers more
than $3 million in cash in the old man's study.
THE NANNY DIARIES, by Emma McLaughlin and Nicola Kraus. (St. Martin's,
$24.95.) A satirical look at rich and powerful New Yorkers through the eyes of an
Upper East Side nanny.
WIDOW'S WALK, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $24.95.) The lawyer for a sexy
young woman whose much older millionaire husband has been shot to death hires
the Boston private eye Spenser to investigate.
THE COTTAGE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $26.95.) An aging, virtually
penniless Hollywood star decides to rent out part of his house.
ATONEMENT, by Ian McEwan. (Nan A. Talese/ Doubleday, $26.) A chronicle of
the disintegration of an English family's idyllic life.
THE STONE MONKEY, by Jeffery Deaver. (Simon & Schuster, $25.) A
quadriplegic forensics genius tries to capture a notorious smuggler of human
beings.
UP COUNTRY, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $26.95.) A Vietnam veteran
investigates the death of an Army lieutenant three decades earlier.
THE PURSUIT, by Johanna Lindsey. (Morrow, $25.95.) A Scotsman falls in love
with a beautiful woman whose family is determined to destroy him.
THE ENGLISH ASSASSIN, by Daniel Silva. (Putnam, $25.95.) An art restorer who
doubles as an Israeli spy becomes entangled in a series of murders.
THE CORRECTIONS, by Jonathan Franzen. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) A
multigenerational saga in which a mother tries to bring her dysfunctional family
together for a final Christmas at home.
JOURNEY THROUGH HEARTSONGS, written and illustrated by Mattie J. T.
Stepanek. (VSP Books, $14.95.) A collection of poems by an 11-year-old boy who
suffers from muscular dystrophy.
THE DIARY OF ELLEN RIMBAUER, edited by Joyce Reardon. (Hyperion,
April 7, 2002
Non-Fiction
STUPID WHITE MEN, by Michael Moore. (ReganBooks/ HarperCollins, $24.95.)
The man behind "Roger & Me" takes aim at Republicans and Democrats,
corporate America and our "nation of idiots."
REPORT FROM GROUND ZERO, by Dennis Smith. (Viking, $24.95.) The author
of "Report From Engine Co. 82" provides accounts of the attack on the World
Trade Center and the rescue efforts that followed.
BIAS, by Bernard Goldberg. (Regnery, $27.95.) A television journalist who worked
at CBS for many years reports on "how the media distort the news."
BLINDED BY THE RIGHT, by David Brock. (Crown, $25.95.) The author of "The
Real Anita Hill" and "The Seduction of Hillary Rodham" recounts his break with the
conservative movement.
SHAKEDOWN, by Kenneth R. Timmerman. (Regnery, $29.95.) A journalist's
"investigative biography" of the Rev. Jesse Jackson.
LOVE, GREG & LAUREN, by Greg Manning. (Bantam, $24.95.) The journal of a
man whose wife, a senior vice president at Cantor Fitzgerald, suffered burns over
82.5 percent of her body on Sept. 11.
ONE NATION, by the editors of Life magazine. (Little, Brown, $29.95.)
Photographs and essays dealing with the events of Sept. 11.
DRIVER #8, by Dale Earnhardt Jr. with Jade Gurss. (Warner, $23.95.) The race
car driver's account of his rookie year on the Nascar circuit.
SACRED CONTRACTS, by Caroline Myss. (Harmony, $25.) Reflections on
"spiritual energies" and the meaning of life.
THE DEATH OF THE WEST, by Patrick J. Buchanan. (Thomas Dunne/St.
Martin's, $25.95.) The right-wing pundit and former presidential candidate argues
that "immigrant invasions" threaten Western culture.
WHAT WENT WRONG? by Bernard Lewis. (Oxford University, $23.) A scholar of
Middle Eastern history examines the reaction of the Islamic world to being
overshadowed by the West.
JOHN ADAMS, by David McCullough. (Simon & Schuster, $35.) A biography of
the country's first vice president and second president.
SHADOW WARRIORS, by Tom Clancy with Carl Stiner and Tony Koltz. (Putnam,
$29.95.) An inside look at the United States' special-operations forces.
THE UNIVERSE IN A NUTSHELL, by Stephen Hawking. (Bantam, $35.) A
